column1: Florida Atlantic Takes Sunshine Slam Semifinal
column2: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team is heading to the Sunshine Slam's championship game after defeating Loyola Marymount by a score of 64-52 on Monday night at the Ocean Center. The Owls (5-1) delivered the Lions' (6-1) their first loss of the season in the tournament's semifinal matchup behind junior guard Kanaan Carlyle's second consecutive 20-point outing and redshirt sophomore Devin Vanterpool with another all-around performance highlighted by his 14 points and a relentless defensive effort. FIRST HALF The Owls jumped out to an early lead with Carlyle, whose momentum carried over from the previous game, with a four-point play three minutes in. FAU's lead grew to as much as 13 before LMU went on a run to close the gap to four. An offensive drought was ended by a ferocious driving dunk from Xander Pintelon, part of a perfect first half from the field for the junior forward. The hot shooting start continued up to the final buzzer, with Vanterpool drilling an attempt from beyond the arc in the closing seconds to send the Owls into the locker room with a 41-34 lead. SECOND HALF LMU worked its way back into the game, cutting the deficit to four in the opening minutes of the final period. The Owls never surrendered the lead, responding with a 12-2 run over the course of four minutes to go up by 11. The Lions had one more run in them to trail by two with just under 10 minutes remaining, but Florida Atlantic soon built its lead back up to double digits, this time from attacking the paint. An explosive sequence by Vanterpool on both ends of the floor ensued, soaring for a two-handed block to deny a dunk attempt despite a four-inch height disadvantage, and then swishing a step-back jumper. It was all FAU the rest of the way, surrendering just two field goals to the Lions in the final five minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE GALLERY Gallery: (11-24-2025) MBB vs. LMU STATS & NOTES For the third time in four seasons, Florida Atlantic has won four out of its first five games. The Owls have not trailed at any point in their last four victories. With 24 points, Carlyle reached a new FAU career high for the second straight game. Redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams, the team's leader in blocks, totaled three in the first half and finished the night with a career high of four. Pintelon hauled in nine rebounds, the most by an Owl on the season. The team won the rebounding battle over the Lions 42-29. UP NEXT The champion of the Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket will be determined in the matchup between Florida Atlantic and George Mason on Tuesday, Nov. 25, at 7:30 p.m. on CBS Sports Network. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Owls’ Comeback Comes Up Short in Sunshine Slam Title Game
column2: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team erased a 19-point second half deficit but ultimately fell to George Mason, 74-65, in the Sunshine Slam championship game on Tuesday evening at the Ocean Center. In the title game for the 2025 Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket, the Owls (5-2) embarked on a 12-0 run over the Patriots (7-0) with less than 11 minutes remaining, bringing the game within one possession multiple times in the final moments. Redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool was once again an FAU spark plug, scoring 17 points on 6-for-9 shooting to go with his team-best nine rebounds and five assists to earn a spot on the Sunshine Slam's All-Tournament team. FIRST HALF The Owls' early offensive success came from three-point range, with the first nine points coming from beyond the arc. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle and Devin Vanterpool combined for 21 of the team's 25 points. Florida Atlantic closed the gap on the double-digit deficit, trailing by nine with one minute remaining, before two straight triples from George Mason sent the Owls into the locker room trailing 40-25. SECOND HALF Leaning on the inside game to start the final period, the Owls converted seven of their first 11 attempts, all coming from the paint. With under 11 minutes remaining, the Patriots took a game-high 19-point lead. Then, the Florida Atlantic comeback was on, going on its 12-0 run while holding George Mason without a field goal for nearly five minutes. The Owls' gap continued to close, led by Vanterpool and redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou, who checked in for the first time of the night with 12 minutes to go and scored seven points. Vanterpool attacked the rim and converted a three-point play to bring the game within single digits, followed by an Amkou layup off a George Mason turnover to cut the lead to three points at the two-minute mark. Redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams tipped in a missed shot to put the game within one possession once again with 38 seconds left, but the Patriots converted six free throws down the stretch to end the valiant comeback effort. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Carlyle led the way in scoring with 22 points, the first Owl to record 20+ in three straight games since Vlad Goldin in 2024. Vanterpool's nine rebounds are a new career high. He has recorded at least five in each of the first seven games. With three on the night, Williams had his fourth consecutive game with at least three blocks. He has recorded multiple in six out of seven games on the season. The Owls outscored the Patriots 38-26 in the paint. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close out the month of November by hosting St. Bonaventure on the 30th at 3:30 p.m. at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on ESPN2. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Second-Half Surge Powers Owls Past Air Force
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – A big second-half surge helped to lead the Florida Atlantic Owls past the Air Force Falcons, 76-71, on Thursday at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls improve to 3-3 overall, and Air Force falls to 3-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED Air Force opened the contest on an 8-4 run, but the Owls answered back with an 8-4 run of their own, capped off by Vivian Onugha's first basket of the day, to tie things up at 12-12 with just under three minutes remaining in the first. FAU took the lead at 17-14, but an Air Force triple tied the back-and-forth contest at 17-all to close the first. The Falcons retook the lead to open the second, 21-17. Destyne Jackson brought the Owls back within two at 21-17 at the 7:40-minute mark. Air Force capitalized on numerous FAU errors as the Falcons went on a 13-4 run to hold a 13-point lead with 2:37 to go in the half. Air Force maintained its 13-point lead through the final minutes of the opening half until Jess Moors knocked down her first triple of the day to cut the deficit to 10 before the break at 36-26. The Owls refocused at the half, turning the tide in the third period. Capitalizing on numerous Air Force turnovers, FAU produced a dominant 19-7 run, capped off by a triple from Madi Gewirtz, to retake the lead 45-43. Zahira Arizmendi hit her first triple of the day to extend the Owls' lead to five, 50-45, but the Falcons closed the quarter with a three to cut the Owls' lead to 55-53. A pair of Air Force free throws tied things up at 55 to open the fourth, but the Owls responded with a 9-2 run to build their lead back to seven, 64-57, with 5:35 to play. The Falcons went on another run, outscoring the Owls 8-4, cutting the lead to three, 68-65, with just under three minutes to play. However, a layup from Moors and back-to-back free throws from Haley Walker and Moors pushed the Owls' lead back to eight, 74-66, with 24 seconds remaining. The Owls maintained their advantage, but a late Air Force triple closed out the 76-71 contest in favor of the Owls. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I felt like we fought really hard to get back in the game. We started out extremely flat, which I believe is due to the physicality of the game on Monday, so we had to get refocused at half. Our full-court pressure definitely got us back in the game and enabled us to force the turnovers we needed to score some easy buckets. NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double figures in the win. Moors led the way for the Owls with a team-high 15 points, shooting 57 percent (4-of-7) from the field, 50 percent (1-of-2) from 3-point range, and going a perfect 100 percent (6-of-6) at the line. Moors also dished out a team-best three assists and collected three steals and a board in the win. Jackson and Onugha rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, tallying 14 points apiece. Onugha finished with a team-leading seven boards and added a block in the contest. The Owls had a strong second-half performance, outscoring the Falcons 40-35 in the final two periods. FAU outshot Air Force at all three levels, outpacing the Falcons from the field, 59.6 to 44.6 percent, from beyond the arc, 50 to 42.1 percent, and at the line, 78.9 to 76.5 percent. The Owls also outrebounded the Falcons, holding a 29-23 advantage on the glass. UP NEXT The Owls have a short turnaround as they get ready for a Friday matchup against the Wright State Raiders. Tipoff is scheduled for 1 p.m. on ESPN+ inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Owls Win Overtime Thriller Over Wright State
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team completed the comeback to win an overtime thriller 66-65 over the Wright State Raiders at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Friday. The Owls improve to 4-3 overall, while Wright State falls to 4-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED A slow start saw the Owls fall behind 9-2 over the first six minutes of play. Michiyah Simmons started to get the offense going with a 3-pointer a minute later, 9-5, and a layup from Jess Moors off a steal made it a two-point game, 9-7, at the 3:23-minute mark. The Owls kept things within two to close the first quarter, 11-9. FAU continued to trail into the second quarter, keeping it close at 13-12 through the seven-minute mark. However, Wright State began to pull away, going up by six points at 18-12. Grace Carstensen got her first points of the game, starting a 5-0 run to bring Florida Atlantic within a point, 18-17. But the Raiders responded, going on a 6-0 run of their own to close out the half to make it a 24-17 ballgame at the break. Madi Gewirtz opened the scoring in the third, knocking down a pair of free throws, 24-19. Wright State then went on an 11-5 run to extend its lead to as much as 11, 35-24, through the 6:08-minute mark. However, the Owls fought back, combined a pair of runs, a 5-0 run, followed by an 8-0 run, to make it a one-possession game, 39-37, entering the final 10 minutes of play. Wright State extended its lead back to five, 42-37, after a trio of free throws to start the fourth. Vivian Onugha led the comeback for the Owls, contributing seven points to put Florida Atlantic ahead by two for their first lead of the game at 46-44. The back-and-forth battle continued, with Jess Moors tying it up in the final seconds to send the game into overtime tied at 56. The back-and-forth battle continued into overtime. The Owls took the lead 58-56 to open overtime after a pair of free throws from Gewirtz, but the Raiders answered back on an 8-1 run to retake a five-point lead, 64-59. FAU fought back on a 6-1 run, capped off by a Simmons three, to tie things up once again at 65 with 23 seconds to play. Carstensen put the owls up by one with six seconds to go off a free throw. Wright State had the final possession, but Moors intercepted the inbound pass to close out the final seconds and seal the Owls' 66-65 win. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND I'm really proud of our effort today. It was a complete team win. I thought we fought for 45 minutes. Even though it wasn't pretty offensively, I thought we had a great defensive effort and followed the game plan extremely well. We had some big plays down the stretch, Jess Moors' layup in transition to put us into overtime, and then her steal late came up huge. Also, Michiyah Simmons, I thought she had some big plays offensively to keep us in the game. But overall, a great team win, and really proud of this team for continuing to fight and never giving in." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double digits on the day. Destyne Jackson and Simmons each had a team-high 12 points. Jackson shot 42 percent (5-of-12) from the field and 29 percent (2-of-7) from beyond the arc, while Simmons shot 33 percent (3-of-9) from the field, 40 percent (2-of-5) from 3-point range, and went a perfect 100 percent (4-of-4) at the line. Gewirtz rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, finishing with 11 points, shooting 75 percent (3-of-4) from the field and going a perfect 100 percent (5-of-5) at the line. Haley Walker led the team on the glass with 11 rebounds, while Onugha finished second with nine boards in the win. The Owls dominated the Raiders on the boards, outrebounding Wright State 50 to 37, including a 21-11 advantage on the offensive glass. FAU also earned a big advantage in points off the bench as the Owls' reserves outscored Wright State 23 to eight in the win. UP NEXT The Owls head to Bowling Green, Kentucky, to face Western Kentucky on Wednesday, Dec. 3, at 7:30 p.m. at E.A. Diddle Arena and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Florida Atlantic Falls in Season Finale
column2: BOCA RATON, FLA. – The Florida Atlantic football team was defeated by East Carolina by a score of 42-3 on Saturday afternoon at Flagler Credit Union Stadium to close the 2025 season. With the clock winding down in the first quarter, redshirt junior WR Easton Messer nearly took a punt return to the house, stepping out of bounds at the Pirates' 10-yard line after cutting across the field for 60 yards. The Owls (4-8, 3-5) settled for a field goal by redshirt senior kicker Garrison Smith for their only points of the afternoon before holding ECU (8-4, 6-2) scoreless in the second half. As part of a Senior Day ceremony, the following players were recognized pregame: DL Kiemar Brown-Richardson, WR Jett Coolman, DB Daniel Johnson, DB Chris Keys Jr., TE Michael Kirch, LS Jackson Lee, P Logan Lupo, WR Devarius Mitchell, DB Terez Reid, K Garrison Smith, OL Michael Unis, OL Scarlee Jean, DB Wendol Philord, DL Bryce Langston, and OL Alex Atcavage. VIDEO RECAP OFFENSE With 10 receptions for 86 yards, redshirt junior WR Easton Messer finishes the season with 104 catches and 1,052 receiving yards. He is just the second Owl to record 100+ receptions in a season and finishes third all-time in single season receiving yards in program history. Redshirt junior Caden Veltkamp and graduate QB Zach Gibson combined for 299 passing yards. They logged 275+ yards through the air in all 12 games of the 2025 season, the first Owl offense to accomplish this in program history. DEFENSE Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky led the way with 12 tackles. It was his fifth game in 2025 to record 12+, putting him in elite company with Azeez Al-Shaair as the last Owl to do so in one season. Following Stolsky's lead, redshirt junior LB Leon Hart Jr. added nine tackles to finish the year with 97. He and Stolsky are the first Florida Atlantic duo since Rashad Smith and Akileis Leroy in 2019 to each have 90+ tackles in a season. With five on the afternoon, redshirt senior DB Dillion Williams reached 100 career tackles. Freshman DE Josh Roberts notched a sack, his third of the season, and forced a fumble in the process. SPECIAL TEAMS Messer's 60-yard punt return was the fourth longest in school history. He set the single-season program record in average yards per punt return (minimum 10 attempts) at 20.8. Redshirt senior kicker Garrison Smith finishes the season converting 84% (16-for-19) of his field goal attempts, the highest in one season in program history. He connected with all 36 of his extra point attempts, making him a perfect 108-for-108 in his collegiate career. The Owls have not missed a kicked point after touchdown since 2021. POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid vs ECU PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-29-2025) ECU at Florida Atlantic FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team fell 70-65 to St. Bonaventure to close out the month of November in the Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls (5-3) returned to Boca Raton to take on the Bonnies (7-1) of St. Bonaventure for the first game of the home-and-home series. Redshirt sophomore Devin Vanterpool records the first double-double of his career with 17 points and 10 rebounds. He was one of the two in double figures for Florida Atlantic on the day. FIRST HALF Sophomore Isaiah Elohim got things started for the Owls with the first basket of the game. St. Bonnies then scored five points to take the lead 5-2. Vanterpool hits a jumper in the paint to make the game 5-4. At the first media timeout of the game at 15:46, the Owls were down 9-5. Maxim Logue scored eight points in the first half, giving Florida Atlantic some momentum with back-to-back dunks. The Owls went into the locker room down by two, winning the rebound battle 19-15. SECOND HALF St. Bonaventure scored on three consecutive possessions to improve their lead to 41-32. Vanterpool hit his second three-pointer of the game for the first bucket of the second half for FAU. Redshirt freshman Amar Amkou totaled eight points in the final 20 minutes. While forward Devin Williams tallied two more blocks for a total of five on the afternoon. With less than three minutes left, Vanterpool hits one beyond the arc to cut the deficit. Williams added a rebound and a dunk to his stat line to bring the Owls down by one possession, 68-65. St. Bonnies hit two free throws late to increase their lead to five points. PRESS CONFERENCE GALLERY Gallery: (11-30-2025) MBB vs. St. Bonaventure STATS & NOTES The Owls led the rebound battle 37-29. Vanterpool with the first double-double of the season for FAU. Florida Atlantic recorded 16 second-chance points, while St. Bonaventure recorded only four. Williams leads the American in blocks with a total of 23 and is ranked No. 9 in the nation. His performance today marked the fifth consecutive game with 3+ blocks. Guard Amkou records his career-high of 12 points off the bench. Junior Kanaan Carlyle totaled five assists on the day. UP NEXT The Owls will travel to Fort Myers, Fla., to take on the Eagles of FGCU on Saturday, Dec. 7 on. Tip-off is scheduled for 2 p.m., airing on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Dominant Third Quarter Powers Owls to Road Win Over WKU
column2: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. – A dominant third quarter performance helped power the Florida Atlantic Owls to a 47-44 road win against Western Kentucky on Wednesday evening at E.A. Diddle Arena. The Owls improve to 5-3 while Western Kentucky falls to 3-5 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED Destyne Jackson had the first points of the night to put the Owls in front early. Western Kentucky took the lead at the 6:13 mark to make the score 6-5. WKU kept the lead for the remainder of the quarter. FAU was able to keep it close, however, heading into the second quarter down 14-11. Jackson led the Owls in scoring in the first, collecting seven of the Owls' 11 points. Western Kentucky extended its lead to five at the beginning of the second. Madi Gewirtz had her first points of the night with a 3-pointer to bring the Owls back within two at 16-14. WKU extended its lead to seven, 23-16, however, Grace Carstensen knocked down her first 3-pointer of the day, bringing the score to 19-23. The Owls headed to the locker room trailing by six, 27-21. FAU came out of the locker room on fire in the third quarter. Jess Moors started a 15-2 run for Florida Atlantic, giving the Owls a 36-29 lead just four minutes into the second half. Zahira Arizmendi contributed 11 points to this run with three 3-pointers and a layup. The Owls held Western Kentucky scoreless for over seven minutes, heading into the fourth quarter with FAU up 42-36. The fourth quarter started slowly for both sides. In the first seven minutes, Western Kentucky put up four points while the Owls were held scoreless. At the 2:40 mark, WKU tied the game, but the Owls immediately answered with another 3-pointer from Arizmendi, retaking the lead 45-42. The Owls were able to hold on through the remainder of the contest to claim the 47-44 win. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "Great win on the road. I thought our players played really hard, and any win on the road is a great win. I do think that we can continue to improve, but I was really impressed with our defensive effort and how hard we played to earn the win on the road." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Arizmendi led the way for the Owls, scoring a career-high 14 points, shooting 50 percent (5-of-10) from the field and from beyond the arc (4-of-8). Haley Walker led the Owls once again on the glass, collecting nine boards. Moors had a team-leading six assists in the win. GALLERY Gallery: (12-3-2025) Florida Atlantic WBB at Western Kentucky UP NEXT The Owls return home for a two-game homestand, beginning with Florida Gulf Coast on Friday, Dec. 12, at 11 a.m. inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Two Owls Set for Toyota U.S. Open
column2: AUSTIN, Texas - Daniel Laureyssens and Leyton Roe of the Florida Atlantic men's swimming team are set to travel to Texas, ready to compete in the 2025 Toyota U.S. Open, taking place Wednesday, Dec. 3 through Saturday Dec. 6. This meet provides an opportunity for Owl swimmers to qualify for the national team of their home country. This meet has been approved by World Aquatics to serve as a qualifying event for the World Aquatics Swimming Championships (25m) - Beijing 2026. Long course competition begins Wednesday at 5 p.m., followed by prelims Thursday-Saturday at 10 a.m. with finals each night beginning at 7 p.m. Name Event(s) Entered Laureyssens​​​ 50 free, 100 free, 200 free, 200 fly Roe​​​​ 50 free, 100 fly, 200 fly LAST TIME OUT At the Patriot Invitational, Laureyssens continued to break records for FAU, setting a new 50 free program record in the prelims before besting it in the finals, swimming 19.57. In the 200 free, he swam 1:33.95, 0.02 seconds shy of the NCAA Championship standard and broke former Owl Olympian and national champion Bela Szabados's 29-year-old record. Laureyssens then broke the 100 free program record for third time this season, this time lowering to 42.77. Roe, in his first midseason meet as an Owl, finished second in the 50 free (19.73) to set a new personal record and his first time breaking the 20 second barrier. He also finished fourth in the 100 free, swimming a time of 44.46. ON DECK Select Owl swimmers will participate in the CSCAA Open Water National Championship on December 13, in Nathan Benderson Park, located in Sarasota, Florida. The next official meet for Florida Atlantic will be on December 15 in Coral Cables, Florida, as the Owls face the University of Miami women's team and Cincinnati. SCHEDULE For the full 2025-26 swim & dive schedule, click HERE. ROSTER For the full 2025-26 swim & dive roster, click HERE. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage from the meet and more FAU swimming & diving news, follow along on social media platforms (@fauswimdive).

BOCA RATON, Fla. – As part of college football's National Signing Day on Wednesday, Dec. 3, Florida Atlantic football is welcoming 13 new additions to its 2026 roster. The signing class marks Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley's first at the helm of a program. VIDEO RECAP SIGNEES (Name | Position | Hometown | Previous School) Owen Pollock | TE | Sunbury, Oh. | Big Walnut "Owen is a well-rounded TE who is tough, physical, possesses great ball skills and an elite work-ethic. A multi-sport athlete that we expect to contribute early in his career," said Coach Kittley. Aedyn Buchanan | OT | Greensboro, N.C. | Page "Aedyn is a long, athletic offensive tackle with a huge ceiling for us. Plays with an edge and has the potential to make a big impact for us in the future." Travis Jackson | DB | Wellington, Fla. | Palm Beach Central "Travis is a local senior who lined up weekly and shut down the opponents best wideouts with his speed and advanced coverage skills." Antojuan Woody | WR | Camp Hill, Ala. | Northeastern Oklahoma A&M "Woody is an elite playmaker and a threat to score every time the ball is in his hands. Whether it's at wide receiver or returner, he is an electric athlete." Kam Herring | DB | Memphis, Tenn. | East Central CC "Kam is a lengthy corner who has great ball skills with elite change of direction and a knack for physicality. He will provide an immediate impact in the secondary." Elijah West | WR | Pensacola, Fla. | Tate "Elijah is a Power 4 talent with elite ball skills who plays fast and physical. He has a huge ceiling and a bright future in the offense here at FAU." Roman Garcia | EDGE | Wagoner, Okla. | Northeastern Oklahoma A&M "Roman is an extremely hard-nosed football player with a wrestling background. He plays the game with unmatched violence and toughness who will bring an immediate contribution to the EDGE room." Jeremiah Daoud | QB | McKinney, Texas | Allen "Jeremiah is a proven winner, one of the best QBs in Texas and leads one of the best teams in the country." Javery Mayberry | TE | Gilbert, Ariz. | Pasadena City "Javery is a playmaking TE who shows elite ball skills and run after the catch ability. His game will translate to our offense seamlessly with a big upside in the near future." Alejandro Schmitt | OT | Pembroke Pines, Fla. | West Broward "Alejandro is a strong and athletic offensive lineman who shows position flexibility up front for us. He comes from one of the top high school programs in South Florida." Sean Williams | DB | Fairburn, Ga. | Creekside "Sean is a true cover corner who plays for one of the top programs in the state of Georgia. His athleticism shows on tape and will elevate the room." Nicsaint Joseph Jr. | WR | Miami, Fla. | Miami Northwestern "Nicsaint is a long receiver who can run, shows elite body control and ball skills. Playing a significant role in the offense of a top team in the state of Florida, his game translates to our offense perfectly." Owen Cheatham | OL | Durango, Co. | Durango "Owen is another long, athletic player who comes from Colorado. We saw serious potential in his ability and plays the game the right way with the physicality and toughness we are looking to add in the room." FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

column1: Coach Jakus Meets with Media on Wednesday
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic men's basketball Head Coach John Jakus met with the media on Wednesday to discuss the matchup at FGCU on Sunday, Dec. 7, for the second road game of the season. Jakus spoke about the importance of playing on the road early to prepare for the rest of the season. He also touched on the preparation for facing the Eagles in Fort Myers, Fla., at Alico Arena on Sunday, Dec. 7. Tip-off is scheduled for 2 p.m. and will air on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Horan and Diaz Named to All-South Region Teams
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. -- Florida Atlantic women's soccer forward Michelle Horan and defender Daniella Diaz have been selected to the 2025 United Soccer Coaches All-South Region teams. The organization announced this week. Senior Horan was named to the second team, while Diaz was named to the third team. Both concluded their collegiate journey as an Owl and contributed on and off the field for Florida Atlantic. Horan and Diaz continue to reserve accolades this season. The two started as American Players to Watch, and Horan was named American Second Team All-Conference. The Cape Coral native played all four years at FAU and became a vital piece to the offense to close out her collegiate career. Horan totaled seven assists on the season, bringing her total to 14. She recorded two goals this season and led the Owls with 17 shots on goal. Horan hit the game-winning goal at Jacksonville when the Owls went into halftime with a score of 2-2. With 58:55 on the clock, Horan scored the third goal of the match to put FAU on top and head back to Boca Raton with a win. This season, she appeared and started in all 19 games. Horan concludes her career with 70 games played and 43 starts. Diaz, a senior defender, finished her career as an Owl with a total of 5,139 minutes, playing the full 90 minutes in 31 games. This season, she registered a goal and an assist with two shots on goal. The defender concluded her career with two goals, both scored during her final two seasons at FAU. Diaz was a primary defender for the Owls for the past three seasons, contributing to a total of 21 shutouts throughout her career. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things Florida Atlantic women's soccer, follow the team on social media @FAUWSoccer.

column1: Fonzetti and Sharp Named November Student-Athletes of the Month
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic Athletics has named its Prestige Windows & Doors Student-Athletes of the Month for November with Bullion Sharp from men's tennis and Natalia Fonzetti from cheer earning the honors. The monthly awards are presented to a male and female Florida Atlantic student-athlete to recognize their excellence in the classroom. FAU's athletic academic staff votes on the award. These are the first honors for this duo. QUOTABLE "Bullion has had an outstanding start to his college career this fall 2025 semester. He continues to maintain a perfect record of straight A's since beginning at FAU. I appreciate his hard work and positive attitude. Bullion has a bright future!" -– Hannah Smith, FAU's Assistant Director of the Student Athlete Success Center. "Nat is recognized as our Student-Athlete of the Month for her leadership, positivity, and commitment on and off the mat. In addition to excelling as a member of the cheerleading team, she actively supports the Student-Athlete Advisory Committee (SAAC), contributing to campus engagement and student-athlete initiatives. Her dedication and willingness to help make her a standout representative of our program." – Toya Ballard, FAU's Senior Associate AD/Director of Student-Athlete Success Center. STUDENT-ATHLETES OF THE MONTH August - Terez Reid, football, Maja Piotrowicz, women's swimming & diving September - Mamadou Diarra, men's soccer, Stella Rubidoux, women's soccer October – Payne Smith, men's swimming and diving, Vivian Onugha, women's basketball November – Bullion Sharp, men's tennis, Natalia Fonzett, cheer

BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic Owls are heading to Bowling Green, Kentucky, for a midweek matchup against the Western Kentucky Hilltoppers. Tipoff is scheduled for 7:30 p.m. ET on ESPN+ at E.A. Diddle Arena. MATCHUP INFO Florida Atlantic (4-3) vs. Western Kentucky (3-4) Date: Wednesday, Dec. 3 Time: 7:30 p.m. ET Location: Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena in Boca Raton, Fla. GAME COVERAGE TV: ESPN+ Live Stats: SideArm Live Stats A LOOK AT THE OWLS Florida Atlantic enters Wednesday's matchup at 4-3 overall, on a two-game winning streak after finishing the Thanksgiving Classic 2-0 with wins over Air Force, 76-71, and Wright State in overtime, 66-65. As a team, the Owls currently rank in the top five in the American in a few categories, ranking second in the league in field goal percentage (.418), third in free throw attempts per game (21.6), bench points per game (27.3), steals per game (11.4), 3-point percentage (.319), and fifth in free throws made per game (15.0), 3-pointers per game (6.3), and turnovers forced per game (19.3). The Owls' offensive leader is Vivian Onugha, who boasts a team-best 11.4 points per game. Onugha also leads the team in rebounding, collecting a team-leading 7.1 rebounds per contest this season. Jess Moors leads the Owls in assists, dishing out a team-best 2.4 assists per game through seven contests. Moors also paces the team in steals, collecting a team-leading 2.6 steals per game this season. SCOUTING WESTERN KENTUCKY Western Kentucky enters the midweek matchup with a 3-4 overall record. The Hilltoppers snapped a three-game skid with a 60-52 win in their last outing at Southern Illinois. The Hilltoppers are led offensively by Torri James, Salma Khedr, Tia Shelling, Zsofia Teledgy, and Jeniffer Silva. James leads the way for WKU, averaging a team-best 8.9 points per game, while Khedr and Shelling rank second and third, scoring 8.8 and 8.7 respectively. Telegdy leads WKU on the glass, boasting a team-high 5.0 rebounds per game, while James and Mya Pratcher are tied for second, collecting 4.9 rebounds per game each. Trinity Rowe and Shelling are WKU's assist leaders. Rowe has dished out a team-best 4.0 assists per game, while Shelling ranks second with 3.6 assists per contest this season. Shelling paces the Hilltoppers in steals, collecting 2.3 steals per game, and Silva and James lead the team in blocks, tallying 1.6 and 1.4 blocks per contest, respectively. SERIES HISTORY The Owls will look to snap a four-game skid against the Hilltoppers in the 29th all-time meeting on Wednesday. In the last meeting between the two squads, WKU won a 66-65 contest on January 28, 2023, in Bowling Green, Kentucky. LAST TIME OUT: THANKSGIVING CLASSIC The Owls went a perfect 2-0 during the Florida Atlantic Thanksgiving Classic, earning a pair of wins over Air Force, 76-71, and Wright State in overtime, 66-65. Destyne Jackson led the way for the Owls offensively, scoring 26 points over the two contests. Moors dished out a team-leading six assists. Defensively, Onugha led the Owls on the glass, recording a team-high 16 rebounds, and Madi Gewirtz paced the team in steals, recording a team-high six steals across the two contests. UP NEXT The Owls will return to Paradise on Friday, Dec. 12, to host the FGCU Eagles for the Owls' Education Day game. Tipoff is scheduled for 11 a.m. on ESPN+ inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena.
